turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: I'll give you a little hint. You're a smart guy, figure it out.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Agent Mackelway?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: This is Richard Low. Stay on the phone. Do not disconnect. I'm watching you. I will instruct you where to drive.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: When you exit, head east on 10th.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Dave Koessler must have you jumping through hoops.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I believe it is you, sir, who has us jumping through hoops.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: How's the arm?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I've been reading, hearing about you. I spoke to Koessler, Professor Daitz.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: He couldn't break an egg with a hammer. He still writing those crime porn books?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: He's moved on to TV.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: He always had a weakness in that area. I saw it the first time I met him. We all had our weaknesses, I guess. Daitz wanted the money. With Dave it was the glory. Koessler saw the Behavioral Sciences Unit as a stepping stone to bigger and better bureaucratic things. He had his eye on the Director's job, even then. Catching killers was a means to an end for them.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: What was your weakness, sir?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: I'm not sure, exactly. I had monsters on the brain. I wanted to get these guys, every one of them. I got obsessive.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Suspect Zero?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Deputy Director Koessler opposed the theory because it meant pressing the legal envelope, risking high-profile failure. Better to get rid of me. Then he could be Mr. Serial Killer, Mr. Authority on Deviant Behavior -- no embarrassing questions about the contribution of one Richard Low. Do you really think that plane crashed by accident? Do you really think I wasn't on it by accident? I've always had a good sense of intuition.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: So you went underground?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Was I afraid of Dave Koessler? Not likely. I told you, I'd gotten a bit obsessive. It was an opportunity to back off, think things through.  Where's the file?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I don't carry it with me.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: You're a smart guy. Tell me what it says.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: "Agent Low's theory of Suspect Zero, the undetected serial killer, is delusional, the product of good intentions, paranoia and obsession..."

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Hum a tune and I'll sing to it.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: The file, however, was kept open after your death. NPE disappearances, No Plausible Explanation, were sometimes filed there, deleted if the bodies were found.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: It's my master list of missing persons: men, boys, girls, children over the last ten years. Two hundred and eighty-five names. A pool of possible victims.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Zero killed them all?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Of course not. They're possibles. I've checked them against Bureau records, check them against your file. How did you get it?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Daitz hinted it existed. It was a matter of forming the request in the proper terms.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: After my hiatus, after I got my priorities readjusted, I drifted online, started tracking porn chat rooms, looking for Zero. Got accepted, came across these boys swapping stories, pictures, downloads. Never found Zero, but I did come across some Class A scumbags.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: How do you know who's real and who's not?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: And who else did I find? Agent Thomas Mackelway, crackerjack FBI techie. I was greatly disappointed when you were re-assigned.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: You knew it was me all along?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Please. You can't hide from me, sonny. I invented the questionnaire. I can tell those who talk from those who do it in the time it takes you to fart.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: There's someone out there, Mack, I know, some man killing for the fun of it, sniffing human glue, without regard to age or sex, without predicable M.O. Someone who has a way to dispose of the bodies. You have access, you can call up local authorities, check morgues, conduct interviews. Be my man.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I already have an employer.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: If you won't do it for me, do it for your cousin, Nadine, right? The girl in the pink sweater.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Who told you about her?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: You did. You were with her when she disappeared, right? She took you to the mall or the movies, you turn around and she's gone.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: It was the mall.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: I know you, Lionheart. I watched your mind work, heard your dirty thoughts --

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Those were just fantasies.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: We're alike. We are hunters. We have the gift. It's ancient times all over again. We stand between order and chaos. I need help. I can't carry on alone.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Maybe you should back off.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: This guy, Zero, he drifts around, that's how they all start, drifting around, their minds filling up with fantasies. He thinks he's real smart, laughs at us, laughs at his victims. But he has left a trail, and the trail is somewhere in those names. You know how to reach me.  Take my advice, when dealing with these FBI tight-asses, go by the book. That's what I did.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: You? You went by the book?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Yeah, problem was, I had the only copy. See ya.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Is he dead?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: The boy's okay. I saw him...

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Was it Zero?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [Fantasy time, girls, give it up, give it up.]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Lionheart here. I'm back. Sorry about the absence. I had to do some therapy at the crossbar hotel.

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [Reality very risky.]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Whatever happened to MyDick?

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [Lionheart, what happened?]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Something came up, Murman, my man.

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [You want to talk, Lionheart, or you want to take this a little more personal?]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Lead the way, Murman.

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [Follow me.]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I've been to Chicago.

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [Not this way. Call it a little favor, call it a little thing I'm going to do for you. I'm going to make Chicago come alive for you. You'll owe me one.]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: If I owe, I will go.

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [The address is 147 South Rane. It's a lively address. You got a problem with dark meat?]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Haven't had any, but I'm willing to try.

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [Ask for Leslie. Eight days from tonight, exactly one a.m. Be there if you dare. You cannot fool the Murman.]

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [If you wanted a good steak, you should have gone to Omaha.]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Let's go someplace private, Murman, I have something for you.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Let's talk about Zero.

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [Hello, Agent Mackelway. How's the watch? Maybe you can do one of those TV commercials, I found my watch under a serial killer's heart and it was still ticking.]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I want to help you.

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [Not the heart, the watch.]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I've located the Suspect Zero file. Did you know there was one? Koessler ordered it as part of your evaluation.

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [Don't jerk a jerk-off. There's nothing in the Bureau mainframe.]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Not everything is imputed to memory. The most confidential stuff is kept top secret hard copy. Why would the Zero file be kept secret?

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [You tell me.]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: George Sheldon? The second serial killer killed in the manner of his killings. The crime scene profile was never entered into VICAP. At whose request? David Koessler.

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [What does the file say?]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I want to go live with you.

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [And I want to go back to Needlepoint.]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Leave this room, I'll go back with you, blow your cover.

turns.speaker: MURMAN
turns.text: [I don't think so. We want the same thing. See ya.]

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Good morning, sir. Agent Salinas, sir.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: So you're the new meat?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: What did you do to end up here?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I believe it's in my file, sir.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Johnny, get this man's file. Mackelway, right?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Thomas Mackelway.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Hot enough for you, Agent Mackelway? Hell's doorknob. What they got you doing?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Updating the condition of all Bureau- owned vehicles in the southwest sector, sir.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Sounds like fun.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: "Computer Investigation and Infrastructure Assessment Center." Quantico out of MIT -- you're a techie?  Okay, you screwed up once. So did half the guys here. That's why they're here.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I screwed up twice, sir.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: I see that. Washington to Philadelphia to here. Philly's a nice station. How many agents?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Four hundred and sixty, sir.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: "Attitude Adjustment Issues" -- what the fuck is that supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I wished to be reinstated at Computer Crimes. I was undiplomatic in my request.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: This is a first. You criticized the Deputy Director to his face and you still have a badge? You must have some one-of-a-kind skills.  Why don't you just quit? I mean, you're not going to get promoted, not wearing this jacket.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I like working for the Bureau, sir. I like catching bad guys. It's all I care about.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Jesus, just what I need, another blue flamer.  Johnny, get this boy some sun screen.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Agent Mackelway, you want to get off your ass and do something for a change?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Got a vehicle?  Head north on 54. When you get to New Mexico you've gone too far.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Headed there now. The same shift will be on at noon.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: This case has sent bells and alarms ringing all the way to Washington. Your old boss is coming out.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Koessler?

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: The same.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Hope you never do. At first it feels like a sauna, by the time you hit victim four it's a fucking burning shirt factory.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: "MyDick?"

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: MyDick. As in my dick. That was his screen name.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: I don't...

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Eight, nine months ago. When I was at Computer Crime. I got into a chat room with someone named MyDick. I'd talked to him before. Everything I saw yesterday, everything in the autopsies, it's identical. The forensics are dead on. MyDick's fantasies involved a hog-tie rig, nylon cord, torture with pliers, rip the nipples -- when the "item" screams, she chokes. He had a thing about eyes, always the eyes -- stab their eyes. It's the same guy. Speck was MyDick.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Speck is dead.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I talked to him.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: But why attack an Agent?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: He wants us to know he's out there, what he's doing. It's not enough just to kill somebody like Speck, he wants us to know he did it.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: How far is Amarillo?

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: 350 miles.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Now, Mr. Hawkins, when last in Amarillo, where did you get gas?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Locate a jet, we're going to Amarillo.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Excuse me, Agent Mackelway?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: This man, Hawkins, has killed dozens of people. Suspect Zero.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I don't think you understand.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: What is it exactly I don't understand, Agent Mackelway?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Deputy Director Koessler doesn't want Zero. All he cares about is Low.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Perhaps you can explain it to him.  It's Agent Mackelway.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I'm Agent Thomas Mackelway, FBI. There is no way you will escape. Assistant Deputy Director Richard Low is en route with another Agent.  You may know Low by another name. You may know him by the name Murman. I am Lionheart.

turns.speaker: ZERO
turns.text: Murman!

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: He's a brilliant man. Brilliant enough to catch you.

turns.speaker: ZERO
turns.text: Brilliant? You think he caught any of them because he was brilliant? Hardboy? MyDick? Imelda? Ripper? Think about it, how did he locate them?  He found them as Murman. And how did Murder Man find them? With sweet talk and brains? No. He did it with souvenirs. He took them into private rooms, swapped goodies: pictures, panties, jewelry, body parts. Snuff downloads. As bait. That's why I never exchanged with him. He killed girls, oh yeah, harvested them. He had the best stuff. Richard Low is Murman and Murman is one of us.

turns.speaker: ZERO
turns.text: You want to "profile" me? Find out what makes me "tick"? Write about me, go on a talk show, give me a nickname?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: It's over for you.

turns.speaker: ZERO
turns.text: Take your shirt off.

turns.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
turns.text: Michael, this is Grandma. I want to know if you got the part on that television program. I told the whole family and they're very excited to know if...  Skipping message. End of final message.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Shit.

turns.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
turns.text: You have to put things in perspective.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I know, I know.

turns.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
turns.text: You've been through worse.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: You're right. I know.

turns.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
turns.text: Ever since I've known you.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I don't know about that.

turns.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
turns.text: Moving here from New York was much more of an adjustment than this.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: It didn't feel that way.

turns.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
turns.text: That's because it was a challenge. You has control over you're situation. It was hard, but you rose to it.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Okay. I'll think about that. Bye.

turns.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
turns.text: You really should. Life, after all, is really just a series of challenges...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Enough. I've got to use the phone.

turns.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
turns.text: Are you calling Her?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: No. Stop, come on.

turns.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
turns.text: You should call your Grandmother.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Shuddup.

turns.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
turns.text: Don't do it, Mike.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Shut up.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Do you realize that I've been waiting for that call for six months and I cut her off?

turns.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
turns.text: You're money, baby.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: How are you ladies doing this evening?

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: What do you drive?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I'm sorry?

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: What kind of car do you drive?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Oh... a Cavalier.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: You like laughing at the misery of others?

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: I'm sorry, I couldn't help it. Let me make it up to you.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: I've seen you somewhere... Where have I seen you?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: You ever go to the Kelbo's? On Pico?

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: ...maybe...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...Monday nights? I host an open mike...

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: You're a comedian?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: What's that like?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Well, you know, it's tough. A lot of traveling. A lot of hotels... but, you know, it's a dream... and the money's really good. I think I might buy another really expensive imported car after my next gig in Vegas...

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: I know! Starbucks! I served you an espresso at Starbucks.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Are you sure? Maybe...

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: Yes! Remember? You asked me for an application? I introduced you to the manager?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Oh, yeah... Boy, that must've been a while ago.

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: I'd say about two weeks.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Probably a little longer than that, but, whatever.

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: You better pay the man.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Well, thank you...?

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: Nikki.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Thank you, Nikki.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I'm Mike.

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: Hi, Mike. I'm Lorraine.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Like the quiche?

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: Yes. Like the quiche.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I like quiche.

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: I thought real men don't like quiche.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: My reputation seems to have preceded me.

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: Why? You're not a real man?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Not lately.

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: ...so I thought, what the hell, they make movies in L.A., not in Michigan, so I moved here.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Just like that?

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: Well, it wasn't the simple, but yeah.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: How was it hard?

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: Well, I left someone very special behind.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Tell me about it...

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: You too?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: I thought I was going to die.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: It's been six months and I'm just starting to get over it.

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: Oh, God. That's two more than me. Tell me it gets better.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: It does.

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Well, it still sucks, but you start to see that there are advantages to being single.

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: What what? What advantages?

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: What else?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: What else...? Let's see... You have complete freedom.

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: To do what?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I don't know... To grow, to go out. Whatever you want.

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: Anything?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Anything.

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: Like if I meet a handsome young man and I wanted to ask him to dance? I can do that?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Uh, if the guy wants to.

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: You don't think the guy would find me attractive enough to dance with?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Yes. I mean, no. I mean, maybe he would find her, I mean you attractive. Maybe he doesn't like to dance. Maybe all he likes to do is just stand around and drink and smoke and look cool with his buddies who don't dance either...

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: Maybe it doesn't matter if he's a good dancer cause it's a slow song, if that's what he's afraid of.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: No... Maybe that's not the case. Maybe she shouldn't be such a smug little shit because she'd be surprised at what a good dancer he really is, but it's been a long time and he doesn't know if he's ready to...

turns.speaker: BRUNETTE
turns.text: Mike...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Charles! What's up, man?

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Oh. You know.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Did you, um, did you get that pilot?

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: No, man. I know you didn't get it 'cause you wouldn't've asked me. It wasn't that funny anyway...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...piece of shit. Listen, Charles, this is my friend Rob from Back East.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...and boy does it hurt when they ask.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: I don't even tell them about anything I'm close on anymore...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...not until you book it...

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: ...and even then...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...you might get cut out.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: You want to come with us to a party at the Chateau Marmont? They got a bungalow and lots of beautiful babies.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Why not? This place is dead anyway.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: They're out of Glenlivet.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: What else is going on?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Why don't I just wait three weeks and tell her I was cleaning out my wallet and found her number...

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: ...then ask where you met her...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Yeah, I'll tell her I don't remember and then I'll ask what she looks like.  Then I'll ask if we fucked. How's that, Tee? Is that "the money"?

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: My pleasure.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry. How'd your folks take it?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I haven't heard an official "no" yet.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: You haven't told then, huh?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: I still haven't told my folks I didn't get "Deepspace 9". You'd think they'd'a figured it out by now, but Mom keeps asking...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'm considering taking a job as a "Goofy".

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Hey, man. At least it's Disney.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: ...I heard it took four days to light for that shot...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: ...Four days..?

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: I know what you're saying, man. I don't know what to tell you...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: ...I mean, does it have to be "Goofy"? I was playing Hamlet off-Broadway two months ago, for crying out loud...

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Hi, boys, we almost gave up on you.

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: Oh, are we late? There are no clocks in this town.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Well, no harm done. This is Lisa. I'm sorry, I never got your names...

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: No... no... The worst was when I went in for this After-School special and I'm sitting in the waiting room with all these little kids. I see they're all signed in for the same role as me...

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: They were auditioning for the same role as you?

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: Wait... Wait... Listen... So, I check the time and place. I'm where I'm supposed to be. I call my agent... She says they asked for me specifically...

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: It's like, you looked at my tape. You saw my picture. Why did you call me in? You knew I was twenty-four.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: What an asshole.

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: Let me just check on my boy.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Don't worry. He's in good hands.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Always...

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: No matter what... like splitting aces.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Lisa works at the MGM Grand...

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I'm a "Dorothy".

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Oh my God.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Did you get it?

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: The poor thing. Six years?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: ...And she's with someone else.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: The poor thing. I'll make some coffee.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: He's so sweet. He really said that?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I believe it too. He really just wants her to be happy.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: He is so sweet.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: A couple of high rollers like you?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Could you believe it?

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Wait here, I'll get you that martini.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Nah, I didn't really want it anyway. I just wanted to order it.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Can I get you something else? I mean, you shouldn't leave without getting something for free.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: No thanks. Why ruin a perfect night.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: What do you guys do?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I'm a comedian.

turns.speaker: DEALER
turns.text: On the table.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Sorry?

turns.speaker: DEALER
turns.text: You have to lay it on the table.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Uh, I don't want to bet it all.

turns.speaker: DEALER
turns.text: You're not allowed to hand me money, sir. You'll have to lay it on the table if you want me to change it.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Oh... right.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: DEALER
turns.text: You want this in black chips.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Sure, that'll be fine.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Do you have anything smaller?

turns.speaker: DEALER
turns.text: Yes, but I'm afraid this table has a hundred-dollar-minimum bet. Perhaps you'd be more comfortable at one of our lower stakes tables.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Do you ever perform out here? I'd love to see you.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You should. A lot of comics play Vegas.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Well, I'm afraid it's not that easy...

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: There are different circuits... it's hard to explain... you wouldn't understand...

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Who's your booking agent?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Oh? You know about booking agents... I don't, uh, actually have a west coast agent as of yet...

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Well, who represents you back east?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Actually, it's funny you... I'm actually, uh, between...

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: What do you do, Trent?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I'm sure she'll call. Six years is a long time. You don't just break it off cleanly after six years.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I know, but she did. She's with someone else now...

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Already? You poor thing. It won't last.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It's a rebound.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: We were a rebound, and we lasted six years.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Yeah, but how long was the relationship she was rebounding from?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Six years.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Can I check my messages? I have a calling card.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Sure, I guess. The phone's in the back.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Sorry, it's just that...

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I understand.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: You said there are advantages to being single. I want to know what the advantages are.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Well... You can talk to a beautiful woman at a bar without worrying if anyone's watching you.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: Well... This is it.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Listen. I had a great time.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: Me too.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I would love to see you again sometime.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: I'll be around.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: That's not good enough. I want to make plans to see you.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: Let me get a pen out of my car.  Do you have something to write on?

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: You're a comedian?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Yeah. And an actor.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: I'll have to come see you sometime.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: If and when I get a real gig I'll call you.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: It's not going to well?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: When I lived in New York they made it sound like they were giving out sit-coms to stand-ups at the airport. I got off the plane in L.A. six months ago and all I got to show for it is a tan.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: Didn't you tell me to be patient with my career?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...Yeah, but entertainment law isn't something you just jump into...

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: Neither is acting. Not if you're serious about it.  Can I have one of these?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Why, you like the duck with the cigar?

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: Yeah. Nice touch. It's the logo from "You Bet Your Life", right?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Good eye. Not one club owner got it. They all ask me why I got Donald Duck on my card.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: Hey, at least it's not Goofy.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: Well, I should be getting...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...It's really getting late.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: ...home. It's getting late. Yeah.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: Can I give you a ride to your car...?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...Nah. I'm right across the street...

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: ...Which one...?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...The red piece of shit over there...

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: ...well, it suits you...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...get the hell outta here already...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: Hi, Mike?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Lorraine?

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: Are you on the other line?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Yeah, hold on.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: I can call back...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: No, no. Hold on.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Hi. Sorry about that.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: You didn't have to get off the other line. I would've called you back.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: That's okay. I wanted to talk to you.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Hi, Lorraine. Thanks for holding on.

turns.speaker: LORRAINE
turns.text: Listen, Mike. You really didn't have to get off the line. I just wanted to ask you one thing. I know I shouldn't have called, I mean, my friends said I should wait two days... Oh God, I probably sound like such a schoolgirl... It's just that it's tonight only... I mean, it's Sinatra's birthday and they have this thing every year at "The Room". Do you know where that is? It's impossible to find if you've never been there. I don't understand why none of the clubs in Hollywood have signs. Anyway, I'm so bad at this, if you're not busy I thought you might...

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: How's it going? It's been a while...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...Six months.

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: How are you doing?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Fine... I guess. You?

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: Good.  I think about things.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: What kind of things?

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: You know, us.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I thought you met someone else.

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: It doesn't matter. I think about you every day.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: I miss you, Mike.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Why didn't you call?

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: I couldn't. Do you know how hard it's been not to call you? I pick up the phone every night. Whenever that commercial comes on...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...the Michelin commercial...

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: ...Yeah, with the baby in the tire. One time I started to cry right in front of Pierre...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Pierre... That's his name? Pierre? Is he French?

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: No, he's not... Listen I don't want to talk about him. That's a whole other headache. I called because I heard you might be moving back to Queens...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: I heard you might be moving back...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Yeah, uh, I don't think that's gonna be happening any time soon... Listen, can I call you right back? I gotta take this call...

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: I'm not home and going out of town tomorrow for a week. Can't you talk for five more minutes?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I really want to catch up with you, but I've gotta take this call. They're holding. I'll talk with you when you get back in town. Bye.

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: Goodbye. I lov...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: And what if I don't want to give up on her?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You don't call.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: But you said I shouldn't call if I wanted to give up on her.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: So I don't call either way.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: So what's the difference?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: The only difference between giving up and not giving up is if you take her back when she wants to come back. See, you can't do anything to make her want to come back. You can only do things to make her not want to come back.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: So the only difference is if I forget about her or pretend to forget about her.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Well that sucks.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It sucks.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: So it's almost a retroactive decision. So I could, like, let's say, forget about her and when she comes back make like I just pretended to forget about her.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Right... or more likely the opposite.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Right... Wait, what do you mean?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I mean first you'll pretend not to care, not call -- whatever, and then, eventually, you really won't care.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Unless she comes back first.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Ah, see, that's the thing. Somehow they don't come back until you really don't care anymore.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: There's the rub.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: There's the rub.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Thanks, man. Sorry we always talk about the same thing all the time...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hey man, don't sweat it.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...It's just that you've been there. Your advice really helps.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No problem.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Rob, I just want you to know, you're the only one I can talk to about her.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Thanks. Thanks, man.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I don't think I'm gonna take it.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: It's a gig.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I mean, I need the money.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: You're an actor. Find the Zen in the role.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It's definitely a step back for me.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Look, there's not much of a call for Shakespeare in this town.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: There's just something about being "Goofy". Any other Disney character would be fine. There's just this stigma associated with the character.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: What do you want? You're tall.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Do you realize how hard it's going to be to tell my parents? I still haven't told them I didn't get the pilot.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: You tested over a month ago. I'm sure they figured it out by now.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It's like "Hi, Mom. I'm not going to be starring in that sitcom and, oh by the way, I'm Goofy. Send more money."

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Haven't you noticed I didn't mention Michelle once today?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I didn't want to say anything.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I don't know. It's like not talking to a pitcher in the midst of a no hitter.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: What? Like, you didn't want to jinx it?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Kinda.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I don't talk about her that much.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh no?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I didn't mention her once today.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Well, until now. Tend the pin.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: The only reason I mentioned her at all is to say that I'm not going to talk about her anymore. I thought you'd appreciate that.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I do. Good for you, man.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I've decided to get out there.  Go ahead. Play it out.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: You want to hit the town tonight?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I shouldn't, Mike, it's a weeknight.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: What do you have? A Pluto call back?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Sure. Kick me when I'm down.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: How many strokes?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I don't know. Eight or Nine.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'll give you an eight.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: What'd you get?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: An eight.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Looks like we're in a dead heat after one hole. This is turning into quite a rivalry.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: So, if the party starts at eight, why are we first going to a bar at ten?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: To get a drink before we meet the guys for a bite at eleven.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh.  Where is this place?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: It's one of these. For some reason, cool bars in L.A. have to be very hard to find and have no signs out front.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: That doesn't sound too good for business.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: It's kinda like a speakeasy kind of thing. It's kinda cool. It's like you're in on some kind of secret. You tell a chick you've been some place, it's like bragging that you know how to find it. The only way you could know where a place is is if someone who knows brought you there. You have to have someone come before. There is a direct line connecting you back to the original, unequivocally cool, club patrons. It's kinda like Judaism...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Sounds more like Aids...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...That's probably a more appropriate analogy.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Kinda money, huh?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Classy.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I'll get a Dewars rocks...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Bud.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...A Dewars on the rocks and a Bud, please.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I can't get over how cute the girls in this city are.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I know. It's like the opposite of inbreeding. The hottest one percent from around the world migrate to this gene pool.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Darwinism at its best.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I've been around here six months and I still can't get over it.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It's like, every day I see a beautiful woman. I'm not used to that. I'm used to seeing a beautiful woman, I don't know, once a week. I can't handle it.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Wait till summer. I swear, you can't leave the house. It hurts. It physically hurts.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I can't wait till I actually get to touch one of them.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Ah, there's the rub...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: There's the rub.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Charles and me went to network on this pilot together.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I just tested for one...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ...yeah, a month ago.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: ...What's the big deal? Everyone steals from everyone.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Well, let's hit that party.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What's that guy's name? Sue?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Sue. His dad was big Johnny Cash fan.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh, like that song...

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: ..."A Boy Named Sue". I think that's why he's such a bad cat.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Him?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: He's a mean dude. I've seen him smash a guy's face into the curb. He knocked out his teeth... blood... He was just like Boom, Boom, Boom... fuckin nasty shit, man. He's a nice guy though.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: There are so many beautiful women here.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It's unbelievable.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I got to at least try once.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You're a better man than I am, Charlie Brown.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: No, I just promised myself I'd give it a try. I gotta get out there sooner or later.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Go for it, man.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I'm going in. Will you be my wing- man?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'll be your winger.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Thanks, man.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No problem, buddy. You eat anything today?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You haven't been drinking, have you?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: No. Just O.J.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Sorry about what happened at the Dresden. I had no idea...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Don't sweat it. Now I got an L.A. gun story. You should hear the way I tell to the guys back home. He had an Uzi. Mike half-smiles.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You want to talk about it?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: What's the point?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It's been two days. You should call that girl Nikki...
